source: Enhancing mathematical search with names of formulas
target: Enhancing mathematical searches with names of formulas

source: We present a method to enhance the performance of a mathematical search system in this paper .
target: We present a method to enhance the performance of a mathematical search system .

source: Targeting to mathematical formulas that appear in natural language documents , we collect the names of formulas from the surrounding text , and incorpo-rate the correspondence to the search system 's database .
target: By targeting mathematical formulas that appear in natural language documents , we collect the names of formulas from the surrounding text and incorporate the correspondence into the search system 's database .

source: E ectiveness of the proposed approach is shown through experiments using Wikipedia mathematical articles and Wolfram Functions Site data sets .
target: The effectiveness of the approach is demonstrated through experiments using Wikipedia mathematical articles and Wolfram Functions Site data sets .

source: In the current digital environment , the mathematical content being published on the Web is increasing day by day . While more and more mathematical contents being available on the Web , retrieving mathematical contents becomes an important issue for many users .
target: The mathematical content being published on the Web is increasing day by day , and retrieving mathematical content has become an important issue for many users .

source: Teach-ers , students , researchers do need to gain access to mathematical resources for teaching , studying , or obtaining updated information for research and development .
target: Teachers , students , and researchers need better access to mathematical resources for teaching , studying , and obtaining information for research and development .

source: Therefore , users need specialized search systems to nd the formula that is relevant to their requirements .
target: Moreover , users need specialized search systems to find formulas that are relevant to their needs .

source: Internet search engines are able to detect some particular keywords in mathematical formula but they mostly fail to recognize mathematical symbols and constructs such as integral sym-bols , square root symbols , fractions , or matrices .
target: Internet search engines can detect particular keywords in mathematical formulas but they mostly fail at recognizing mathematical symbols and constructs such as integral and square root symbols , fractions , and matrices .

source: There exist some mathematical-dedicated search engines available on the Internet .
target: There are some mathematically oriented search engines on the Internet .

source: Although such engines provide more accurate and relevant results , they usually do not provide enough information for the user .
target: Although such engines provide more accurate and relevant results , they usually do not provide enough information for the user .

source: Furthermore , these systems do not take into account the semantics of mathematical formulas revealed by surrounding natural language text , like the name of the formula and its variables ' descrip-tion .
target: Furthermore , these systems do not take into account the semantics of mathematical formulas as revealed by the surrounding natural language text , e.g . , the formula�fs name or the description of its variables .

source: The Digital Library of Mathematical functions ( DLMF ) project is a mathematical database available on the Web [8 ] .
target: The Digital Library of Mathematical Functions ( DLMF ) project is a mathematical database available on the Web [8 ] .

source: This site provides a major resource of mathematical reference data for special formulas and their applications .
target: This site provides a major resource of mathematical reference data for special formulas and their applications .

source: But full mathematical search is still not available .
target: But even this site does not provide a full mathematical search .

source: Other systems that support mathematical search are MathFind [4 ] , MathWebSearch [3 ] .
target: Other systems that support mathematical searches are MathFind [4 ] , MathWebSearch [3 ] .

source: These systems , however , provide neither similarity structures nor semantic meanings of the formulas .
target: These systems , however , provide neither similarity structures nor semantic meanings of their formulas .

source: The Wolfram Functions Site [7 ] contains large mathe-matical formulas and also provides a semantics search for mathematical formulas .
target: The Wolfram Functions Site [7 ] contains a large number of mathematical formulas and also provides a semantic search for them .

source: This site and some recent works done by Adeel et al . [2 ] and Yokoi and Aizawa [1 ] propose similarity search methods based on MathML but these works do not make use of the semantics of the formulas ' surrounding text , which is considered to be important information sources .
target: This site and some recent work done by Adeel et al . [2 ] and Yokoi and Aizawa [1 ] employ similarity search methods based on MathML but they do not make use of the semantics of the formulas ' surrounding text . // [ ? ? propose is unclear in the sense of a website . ]

source: The work presented in this paper focuses on retrieving mathematical formulas on the Web using mathematical expressions and the surrounding natural language text .
target: The work presented in this paper focuses on retrieving mathematical formulas on the Web by using mathematical expressions and the surrounding natural language text .

source: We describe here in detail our work toward creating a mathematical database that contains for-mulas , their names , their variables ' descriptions and other related information .
target: We describe our work toward creating a mathematical database that contains formulas , their names , variable descriptions , and other related information .

source: We also implement a mathematical search system that use this information as its base knowledge .
target: We implemented a mathematical search system that uses this information as its base knowledge .

source: This information is very helpful when performing mathematical search by reducing the need for formula input and solving the notational variation problem where mathematically equivalent formulas follow di erent notations .
target: This information is very helpful when performing mathematical search by reducing the need for formula input and solving the notational variation problem where mathematically equivalent formulas follow different notations .

source: Relations between formulas and their name could also be used to correct errors in mathematical OCR systems , such as Infty [5 ] .
target: The relationship between formulas and their names can also be used to correct errors in mathematical OCR systems , such as Infty [5 ] .

source: It also provides opportunities to make mathematical better understandable and usable for di erent groups of people with disabilities .
target: It also provides opportunities to make mathematics better understandable and usable for people with disabilities .

target: The remainder of this paper is organized as follows : we present an overview of our framework in section 2 .

source: We then describe the results of our experiments in section 3 .
target: We then describe the results of our experiments in section 3 .

source: Section 4 concludes the paper and gives avenues for future works .
target: Section 4 concludes the paper and gives avenues of future study .

source: Mathematical formulas on the Web has many di erent formats , some of them are LaTeX , and the Mathematical Markup Language ( MathML ) [6 ] .
target: Mathematical formulas on the Web have many different formats , e.g . , LaTeX and Mathematical Markup Language ( MathML ) [6 ] .

source: This makes the search more dif-cult .
target: This diversity makes searches more difficult .

source: In this paper , we use the presentation MathML format for mathematical formulas .
target: In this paper , we shall use the MathML format for mathematical formulas .

source: Formulas with other formats can be easily converted to MathML format using existing freely available tools .
target: Formulas with other formats can be easily converted to MathML format by using freely available tools .

target: For our work , we used LaTeXML Converter , which is freely available at \URL .

target: We automatically collected our mathematical formulas from Wikipedia and the Wolfram Functions Site .

target: Figure 1 shows a page from a mathematical section on Wikipedia and the information we retrieved on this site , besides the mathematical formulas .

source: At this point , we use some heuristics to provide an adequate solution for matching mathematical formulas with their names .
target: We used heuristics to ensure adequate matching of mathematical formulas with their names .

source: These heuristics are based on the type settings and distances between the name strings and formulas in the same page .
target: These heuristics are based on the type settings and distances between the name strings and formulas on the same page .

source: After collecting the mathematical formulas from these resources , we extract keywords for indexing .
target: After collecting mathematical formulas from these resources , we extracted keywords for indexing .

source: The keywords include formulas ' names , operators , variables ' names , and so on .
target: The keywords included formulas ' names , operators , variables ' names , and so on .

source: Our system allows two ways of searching : text content search and formula content search .
target: Our system allows two ways of searching : text content and formula content .

source: In the rst case , users can use the extracted keywords for search , for example : " sin " , " Pythagorean " or " trigonometric functions " .
target: In a text content search , users search with extracted keywords , e.g . , " sin " , " Pythagorean " or " trigonometric functions " .

source: In the second case , users can input the mathematical formulas directly , for example : \MATH .
target: In a formula content search , users directly input the formulas , for example : \MATH .

source: The system then looks for relevant formula names .
target: The system then looks for relevant formula names .

source: If found , it will return other information related with that formula .
target: If found , it will return other information related to that formula .

source: Else , it just looks for mathematical formulas which are similar to the input ( including formulas with similar structure ) .
target: If nothing matching is found , it looks for mathematical formulas which are similar to the input ( including formulas with a similar structure ) .

source: Evaluate a mathematical search system is not an easy task because we do not have any standard for this task .
target: Evaluating a mathematical search system is not an easy task because we do not have any standard for this task .

source: The similarity between mathematical formulas is very subjective .
target: The similarity between mathematical formulas is very subjective .

source: One of the most significant current discussions in the digitization of mathematical and scientific content and its applications is the semantic enrichment of mathematical documents , that is adding or associating semantic tags - usually concepts - to mathematical expressions .
target: One of the most significant discussions regarding the digitization of mathematical and scientific content and its applications is about semantic enrichment of mathematical documents , that is , adding or associating semantic tags - usually concepts - with mathematical expressions .

source: By encoding the underlying mathematical meaning of an expression explicitly , it is possible to interchange information more precisely between systems that semantically process mathematical objects .
target: By encoding the underlying mathematical meaning of an expression explicitly , it is possible to interchange information more precisely between systems that semantically process mathematical objects .

source: The direct application of this is enabling semantic searches for mathematical expressions by understanding the intent of the searcher and the contextual meaning of mathematical terms improve search accuracy .
target: The direct application of this idea enables semantic searches for mathematical expressions whereby the system 's �eunderstanding ' of the intent of the searcher and the contextual meaning of mathematical terms improves search accuracy .

source: It also benefits computer algebra systems , automatic reasoning system and multi-lingual translation systems .
target: It also benefits computer algebra systems , automatic reasoning systems and multi-lingual translation systems .

source: However , as is the case with natural language , the semantic enrichment of mathematical expressions is a non-trivial task .
target: However , as is the case with natural language , semantic enrichment of mathematical expressions is a non-trivial task .

source: - First , mathematical notation , though more rigorous than natural language , is nonetheless at times ambiguous , context-dependent , and varies from community to community .
target: - First , mathematical notation , though more rigorous than natural language , is nonetheless at times ambiguous , context-dependent , and varies from community to community .

source: - Second , the underlying mathematical meaning of an expression need to follow a semantic markup in a semantically rigorous way .
target: - Second , the underlying mathematical meaning of an expression needs to follow a semantic markup in a semantically rigorous way .

source: Because of this , failing to follow the constraint , the computer might not be able to process that expression .
target: Because of this , in failing to follow the constraint , the computer might not be able to process that expression .

source: - The third problem is that new notations tend to be introduced and used as and when needed so a mechanism is required for referring to mathematical concepts outside of the base collection , allowing them to be represented .
target: - The third problem is that new notations tend to be introduced and used when needed so a mechanism is required for referring to mathematical concepts outside of the base collection .

source: The aim of this paper is to introduce a method for automatic mathematics semantic enrichment that capable of analyze and disambiguate mathematical terms .
target: The aim of this paper is to describe a method of automatic semantic enrichment for mathematics that is capable of analyzing and disambiguating mathematical terms .

source: In our research , MathML \CITE Presentation Markup is used to display mathematical expressions and MathML Content Markup is used to convey mathematical meaning .
target: In our research , MathML \CITE Presentation Markup is used to display mathematical expressions and MathML Content Markup is used to convey mathematical meaning .

target: The semantic enrichment task then becomes one of generating Content MathML outputs from Presentation MathML expressions .

source: There are three reasons why we choose MathML markup in our research .
target: There are three reasons why we chose MathML markup in our research .

source: - First , since its first release in 1997 , MathML has grown to become a general format that enables mathematics to be served , received , and processed in a wide variety of applications .
target: - First , since its first release in 1997 , MathML has grown to become a general format that enables mathematics to be served , received , and processed in a wide variety of applications .

source: - Second , MathML can be used to encode both mathematical notation and mathematical content .
target: - Second , MathML can be used to encode both mathematical notations and mathematical content .

source: - Last , large collections of formulas are available in MathML and we can easily assess these collections .
target: - Last , large collections of formulas are available in MathML , and we can easily assess these collections .

source: - In the scope of this paper , we only make use the information within a mathematical expression for disambiguation when translating it to content markup .
target: - In the scope of this paper , we only make use the information within a mathematical expression for disambiguation when translating it into content markup .

target: The prior solution to this problem is SnuggleTeX \CITE , which was proposed by David McKain .

target: The system uses rule-based methods for disambiguation and translation .

target: This solution has two main limitations :

target: - Since it is a hand-written rule-based system , SnuggleTeX requires mathematical knowledge and human effort to develop .

target: - Due to the diversity of mathematical expressions , SnuggleTeX is still considered experimental and has difficulty processing complicated mathematical symbols and expressions .

source: In this paper , we propose an approach that automatically learn the semantics inference from a presentation from parallel markup data .
target: In this paper , we propose an approach that automatically learns semantic inferences in a presentation from parallel markup data . // <The original has too many from to be logically clear . The rewrite is a guess . > .

source: The idea of this approach is based on statistical machine translation .
target: This approach is based on statistical machine translation .

source: The underlying mathematical meaning of an expression is inferred according to the probability distribution $ p( c | p ) $ that a semantic expression $ c $ is the translation of a presentation expression $ p $ .
target: The underlying mathematical meaning of an expression is inferred from the probability distribution $ p( c | p ) $ that a semantic expression $ c $ is the translation of a presentation expression $ p $ .

source: The probability distribution will be automatically learned from data that have both Presentation and Content MathML markup , that is the parallel markup MathML data .
target: The probability distribution is automatically learned from both Presentation and Content MathML markup data , that is , parallel markup MathML data .

source: - First , successfully apply the machine translation techniques to the problem of mathematic semantic enrichment .

source: - Second , mathematics knowledge such as symbol 's meanings or structural relations is automatically learned while training , therefor it is not required mathematics experts nor human effort and it is also easier to update the system given more data .
target: - Second , mathematics knowledge such as a symbol 's meanings or structural relations is automatically learned while training ; therefore , the system requires no human effort or expertise , and it is easier to update with more data .

target: Since new notations keep cropping up , it is important to update the system as quickly as possible .

target: Grigole et al . \CITE proposed an approach to understanding mathematical expressions based on the text surrounding the mathematical expressions .

source: First , a local context C ( 5 nouns preceding a target mathematical expression ) is found in each sentence .
target: First , a local context C ( five nouns preceding a target mathematical expression ) is found in each sentence .

source: For each noun , the system identifies a Term Cluster ( derived from the OpenMath Content Dictionary ) with the highest semantic similarity according to a similarity metric .
target: For each noun , the system identifies a Term Cluster ( derived from the OpenMath Content Dictionary ) with the highest semantic similarity according to a similarity metric .

source: The similarity scores obtained were weighted , summed up , and normalized by the length of the considered context .
target: The similarity scores obtained are weighted , summed up , and normalized by the length of the considered context .

source: The assigned interpretation is the Term Cluster with the highest similarity score .
target: The Term Cluster with the highest similarity score is assigned as the interpretation .

source: To translate mathematical expressions from the Presentation MathML to Content MathML format , a list of rules for translation is required .
target: To translate mathematical expressions from the Presentation MathML into Content MathML format , a list of translation rules is required .

source: Building these translation rules by hand is a large undertaking .
target: Building these translation rules by hand is a large undertaking .

source: Our task is inherently domain specific therefore we propose an approach which is based on statistical machine learning methods that automatically extract these rules from a dataset .
target: Our task is inherently domain-specific ; therefore , we devised an approach based on statistical machine learning for automatically extracting rules from a dataset .

source: Nowadays , statistical machine translation ( SMT ) is by far the most widely-studied machine translation method .
target: Statistical machine translation ( SMT ) is by far the most widely studied machine translation method .

source: SMT uses a very large data set of good translations , that is , a corpus of texts which have already been translated into other language , and then uses those texts to automatically infer a statistical model of translation .
target: SMT uses a very large data set of good translations , that is , a corpus of texts which have already been translated into another language , and it uses those texts to automatically infer a statistical model of translation .

source: The statistical model is then applied to new texts to make a translation .
target: The statistical model is then applied to new texts to make a translation of them .

source: Tree-based or syntax-based SMT can be used for tree-to-tree translation but it has two drawbacks when apply to the problem of translating from Presentation to Content MathML expression .
target: Tree-based or syntax-based SMT can be used for tree-to-tree translation but it has two drawbacks when it is applied to the problem of translating Presentation into Content MathML .

source: - The first drawback is tree-based SMT focus on generating the surface texts rather than the tree structures .
target: - The first drawback is that tree-based SMT focuses on generating surface texts rather than tree structures .

source: While mathematical expressions have strict structures , it fails to fulfill this requirement .
target: Mathematical expressions have strict structures , and it fails to fulfill this requirement .

source: - The second drawback is there are many long mathematical expressions in real-world data and translating long and complex sentences has been a critical problem in machine translation .
target: - The second drawback is there are many long mathematical expressions in real-world data and translating long and complex sentences has been a critical problem in machine translation .

source: To overcome these limitations , we introduced two separated sets of rule : fragment rules and translation rules .
target: To overcome these limitations , we made two separate rule sets : fragment rules and translation rules .

source: The system has three main modules .
target: The system has three main modules .

source: - Preprocessing : processes MathML expressions to remove error expressions or format tags with no semantic meaning .
target: - Preprocessing : This module processes MathML expressions by removing error expressions or format tags with no semantic meaning .

source: - Extracting Rules : given a dataset contains MathML parallel markup expressions , extract the rules for translation .
target: - Rule Extraction : This module is given a dataset containing MathML parallel markup expressions , and it extracts translation rules from it . // <The original is ungrammatical and unclear . The rewrite is a guess . > .

source: - Generating Content MathML : given a mathematical expressions in Presentation MathML markup , and a set of rules , generate Content MathML expressions to enrich the Presentation MathML expressions .
target: - Content MathML Generation : This module is given mathematical expressions in Presentation MathML markup and a set of rules , and it generates Content MathML expressions to enrich the Presentation MathML expressions .

source: The presentation elements of Presentation MathML are divided into two classes : token elements and layout schemata .
target: The presentation elements of Presentation MathML are divided into two classes : token elements and layout schemata .

source: Token elements represent identifier 's names , function 's names , numbers , etc .
target: Token elements represent the identifier 's names , function 's names , numbers , etc . // <the identifier 's names means there is one identifier with possibly many names . If this is what you want to say , it is okay . If not , maybe you mean simply " identifier names " . ><Likewise , maybe you mean " function names " . >

source: Layout schemata build expressions out of parts .
target: Layout schemata build expressions out of parts .

source: By investigating the data from the Wolfram Function Site , we noticed that there are elements that have no specific meaning , they are used for displaying purpose only and most of them are layout schemata .
target: After investigating data on the Wolfram Function Site , we noticed that there are elements that have no specific meaning ; they are used for display purposes only and most of them are layout schemata .

source: For example , the $ <mtext> </mtext> $ or $ <mspace / > $ tags are used to insert some space between expressions .
target: For example , the $ <mtext> </mtext> $ or $ <mspace / > $ tags are used to insert some space between expressions .

source: As a result , in this preprocessing step , these elements are removed .
target: This preprocessing step removes these elements .

source: In this step , we also removed mathematical expressions with error markups such as expressions that have no Content markup .
target: We also remove mathematical expressions with error markups such as expressions that have no Content markup .

source: For simplification , expressions with more than 200 content nodes also be removed .
target: For simplification , expressions with more than 200 content nodes are also removed .

source: In the training phase , we use GIZA++ \CITE for alignment between Presentation MathML terms and Content MathML terms .
target: In the training phase , we use GIZA++ \CITE for aligning Presentation MathML terms and Content MathML terms .

source: Based on the aligned data , we use some heuristics to extract rules which we called " fragment rules " .
target: Based on the aligned data , we use heuristics to extract rules that we call " fragment rules " .

source: Fragment rules are rules that define the translation from Presentation MathML sub-trees to Content MathML sub-trees .
target: Fragment rules are rules that define the translation from the Presentation MathML sub-trees to the Content MathML sub-trees .

source: These rules are applied to break the large Presentation MathML tree into smaller sub-trees while maintaining the structure of output Content MathML trees .
target: These rules are used to break up a large Presentation MathML tree into smaller sub-trees while maintaining the structure of the output Content MathML trees .

source: These rules are extracted based on the fact that translate small tree is easier than translate large one .
target: These rules are extracted based on the fact that translating a small tree is easier than translating a large one .

source: Each rule in fragment rule set is associated with its probability , that is the frequent that rule happened in the training data .
target: Each rule in the fragment rule set is associated with a probability , that is , the frequency at which a rule occurs in the training data .

source: If the sub-trees can not be broken any longer , we extract another rules , which we called " translation rules " , at that point .
target: Once the sub-trees cannot be broken down further , we start to extract other rules , which we call " translation rules " .

source: We then enhances the translation rule set with the translation terms extracted by GIZA++ .
target: We enhance the translation rule set with translation terms extracted by GIZA++ .

source: The pseudo code of the algorithm for extracting fragment rules is described in Algorithm \REF .
target: The pseudo code for extracting fragment rules is described in Algorithm \REF .

source: In the previous steps , we got two sets of rules , fragment rule set and translation rule set .
target: In the previous steps , we get two sets of rules , a fragment rule set and a translation rule set .

source: We then use these rules for translation .
target: We then use these rules for translation .

source: Given a mathematical expressions in Presentation MathML markup , the system will generate Content MathML markup of that expression .
target: Given mathematical expressions in Presentation MathML markup , the system will generate Content MathML markup for each expression .

source: - First , the expression is preprocess to remove non semantic elements .
target: - First , the expression is preprocessed to remove non-semantic elements .

source: - Second , the fragment rule is applied to the expression until it could not be divided any further .
target: - Second , the fragment rule is applied to the expression until it cannot be divided any further .

source: - Third , the small sub-expressions in Presentation MathML markup will be translated into sub-expressions in Content MathML markup using translation rule set .
target: - Third , the small sub-expressions in Presentation MathML markup are translated into sub-expressions in Content MathML markup by using the translation rule set .

source: If no translation rule is found for a sub-expression , that expression is marked as untranslated .
target: If no translation rule is found for a sub-expression , that expression is marked as untranslated .

source: - Last , sub-expressions in Content MathML markup is grouped to form the complete Content MathML expression .
target: - Last , sub-expressions in Content MathML markup are grouped to form the complete Content MathML expression .

source: Before the last step , we add a heuristic translation to translate numbers .
target: Before the last step , we add a heuristic translation to translate numbers .

source: - Tree Edit Distance \CITE : the tree edit distance is the minimal cost to transform A into B using edit operations .
target: - the Tree Edit Distance \CITE : the tree edit distance is the minimal cost to transform A into B using edit operations .

source: There are three types of edit operations : substituting a node , inserting a node , and deleting a node .
target: There are three types of edit operation : substituting a node , inserting a node , and deleting a node .

source: - Translation Error Rate \CITE : translation error rate is an error metric for machine translation that measures the number of edits required to change a system output into one of the references .
target: - the Translation Error Rate \CITE : the translation error rate is an error metric for machine translation that measures the number of edits required to change a system output into one of the references .

source: We call the new metric Tree Edit Distance Rate ( TEDR ) .
target: We called the new metric the Tree Edit Distance Rate ( TEDR ) .

source: TEDR is defined as the rate between ( 1 ) the minimal cost to transform a tree A into another tree B using edit operations and ( 2 ) the maximum number of nodes of A and B .

source: In this paper , we discussed the problem of the semantic enrichment of mathematical expressions .

target: Our experimental results show that our approach based on the statistical machine translation method for translating a Presentation MathML expressions to Content MathML expressions is a significant improvement over prior systems .

source: Improving protein coreference resolution by simple semantic classification
target: Improving protein coreference resolution by simple semantic classification

source: Recent research shows a major part of difficult cases in event extraction for the biomedical domain are related to coreference .
target: Current research has shown that major difficulties in event extraction cases for the biomedical domain are related to coreference .

source: Therefore , coreference resolution is believed to be useful for the improvement of event extraction .
target: Therefore , coreference resolution is believed to be useful for improving event extraction .

source: To address the problem of coreference resolution in molecular biology literature , the Protein Coreference ( COREF ) task was arranged in the BioNLP-ST 2011 as a supporting task .
target: To address coreference resolution in molecular biology literature , the Protein Coreference ( COREF ) task was arranged in the BioNLP-ST 2011 , as a supporting task .

source: However , the shared task results showed that transferring coreference resolution methods developed for other domains to the biological domain was not straight forward , which is supposed to be caused by the domain differences in coreference phenomena .
target: However , the shared task results indicated that transferring coreference resolution methods developed for other domains to the biological domain was not straightforward , due to the domain differences in the coreference phenomena .

source: We studied the contribution of domain-specific information , i .e information indicating the protein type , in a rule-based protein coreference resolution system .
target: We studied the contribution of domain-specific information , including information that indicates the protein type , in a rule-based protein coreference resolution system .

source: In particular , the domain-specific information is encoded into semantic classification modules whose output is used in different components of the coreference resolution .
target: In particular , the domain-specific information is encoded into semantic classification modules for which the output is used in different components of the coreference resolution .

source: We compared our system with the top four systems in the BioNLP-ST 2011 , and surprisingly we found that the minimal configuration has outperformed the best system in the BioNLP-ST 2011 .
target: We compared our system with the top four systems in the BioNLP-ST 2011 ; surprisingly , we found that the minimal configuration had outperformed the best system in the BioNLP-ST 2011 .

source: Analysis of the experimental results showed that semantic classification using protein information has contributed to an increase in performance ( 2.3 % on the test data , and 4 .0 % on the development data , in F-score ) .
target: Analysis of the experimental results revealed that semantic classification , using protein information , had contributed to an increase in performance by 2.3 % on the test data , and 4 .0 % on the development data , in F-score .

source: The use of domain-specific information in semantic classification is important for coreference resolution .
target: The use of domain-specific information in semantic classification is important for coreference resolution .

source: Since such information is difficult to be transferred across different domains , we need to continue seeking for methods to exploit and use it in coreference resolution .
target: Since it is difficult to transfer domain-specific information across different domains , we need to continue to seek methods to exploit and use it in coreference resolution .

source: While named entity recognition ( NER ) and relation or event extraction are regarded as standard tasks of biomedical information extraction ( IE ) , coreference resolution [ 2 , 16 , 30 ] is more and more recognized as an important component of IE for a higher performance .
target: While named entity recognition ( NER ) and relation / event extraction are regarded as standard tasks for biomedical information extraction ( IE ) , coreference resolution [ 2 , 16 , 30 ] is being recognized more and more as an important component of IE to achieve a higher performance .

source: Without coreference resolution , the performance of IE is often substantially limited due to an abundance of coreference relations in natural language text , i .e . , information pieces written in text with involvement of a coreference relation are hard to be captured [ 9 , 14 ] .
target: Without coreference resolution , oftentimes , the IE performance issubstantially limited , due to the abundance of coreference relations in natural language text ; information pieces written in text with the involvement of a coreference relation are hard to be captured [ 9 , 14 ] .

source: There have been several attempts for coreference resolution , particularly for newswire texts [ 7 , 8 , 22 , 23 , 28 , 30 ] .
target: There have been several attempts for coreference resolution ; in particular , they have been for newswire texts [ 7 , 8 , 22 , 23 , 28 , 30 ] .

source: It is also one of the lessons from BioNLP Shared Task ( BioNLP-ST , hereafter ) 2009 that coreference relations in biomedical text substantially hinder the progress of fine-grained IE [ 10 ] .
target: Coreference resolution is also one of the lessons from the BioNLP Shared Task ( BioNLP-ST , hereafter ) 2009 , in which it was communicated that coreference relations in biomedical text substantially hinder the progress of fine-grained IE [ 10 ] .

source: To address the problem of coreference resolution in molecular biology literature , the Protein Coreference ( COREF ) task was arranged in BioNLP-ST 2011 as a supporting task .
target: To address the problem of coreference resolution in molecular biology literature , the Protein Coreference ( COREF ) task was arranged in BioNLP-ST 2011 as a supporting task .

source: This task definition focuses on a specific type of entities , i .e . Protein .
target: This task definition focuses on protein , as a specific type of entity .

source: Figure 1 shows an example text segmented into four sentences , S2 - S5 , where coreferential expressions are shown in brackets .
target: Figure 1 shows an example text segmented into four sentences , S2 - S5 , where coreferential expressions are shown in brackets .

source: In the figure , protein names are highlighted in bold face , P4 - P10 , and targeted anaphoric expressions of the shared task , e.g . pronouns and definite noun phrases , are T29 , and T32 , of which the antecedents are indicated by arrows if found in the text .
target: In the figure , protein names P4 - P10 are highlighted in boldface ; the targeted anaphoric expressions of the shared task ( pronouns and definite noun phrases ) are T29 , and T32 , for which the antecedents are indicated by arrows , if found in the text .

source: In the example , the definite-noun-phrase expression , this transcription factor ( T32 ) , is considered coreferential with the protein mention p65 ( P10 ) .
target: In the example , the definite-noun-phrase expression , this transcription factor ( T32 ) , is considered coreferential with the protein mention p65 ( P10 ) .

source: Without knowing this coreference relation , it becomes hard to capture the information written in the phrase , nuclear exclusion of this transcription factor , which is localization of p65 ( out of nucleus ) according to the framework of BioNLP-ST .
target: Without knowing this coreference relation , it becomes difficult to capture the information written in the phrase , nuclear exclusion of this transcription factor , which is a localization of p65 ( out of nucleus ) , according to the framework of BioNLP-ST .

source: The terminologies used in this paper are similar to those in [ 25 ] .
target: The terminologies used in this paper are similar to those in [ 25 ] .

source: A new term is introduced in the BioNLP-ST is antecedent protein , which indicates the protein mention contained in the antecedent expression , e.g . p65 in T28 .
target: A new term introduced in the BioNLP-ST is antecedent protein , which indicates the protein mention contained in the antecedent expression , e.g . , p65 in T28 .

source: There are other coreferential expressions which are ignored in the context of this COREF task such as this complex and the NF-kappa B transcription factor complex ( Figure 1 ) , since we only focus on the antecedent expressions that contain and point to protein mentions .
target: There are other coreferential expressions , which are ignored in the context of this COREF task , such as : this complex and the NF-kappa B transcription factor complex ( Figure 1 ) , since our focus is on the antecedent expressions that contain and point to protein mentions .

source: The best system in the COREF shared task according to the primary evaluation found 22 .2 % of anaphoric protein references at the precision of 73 .3 % ( 34 .1 % Fscore ) .
target: The best system in the COREF shared task , according to the primary evaluation , found 22 .2 % of the anaphoric protein references at the precision of 73 .3 % ( 34 .1 % F-score ) .

source: This is an encouraging result , since the authors make use of an external coreference resolution tool originally built for the news domain , without much domain adaptation on the main coreference resolution algorithm .
target: The results are promising , since the authors make use of an external coreference resolution tool originally built for the news domain , without much domain adaptation on the main coreference resolution algorithm .

source: Modifications are mostly made to the markable detection component and post processing for the output coreference links [ 11 ] .
target: Modifications are mostly made to the markable detection component and post-processing for the output coreference links [ 11 ] .

source: However , the external coreference tool achieves much lower results on biological texts than that on news texts , from 66 .38 % down to 49 .65 % in MUC-score [ 11 , 27 ] , which is supposed to be caused by domain differences .
target: However , the external coreference tool " s performance drops for biological texts than for news texts , from 66 .38 % to 49 .65 % in MUC-score [ 11 , 27 ] , which is supposed to be caused by domain differences .

source: A detailed analysis on the _nal submissions of the COREF task participants was reported in the organizer 's papers [ 15 , 31 ] , which is summarized in table 2 .
target: A detailed analysis on the _nal submission of the COREF task participants was reported in the organizer 's papers [ 15 , 31 ] , and is summarized in table 2 .

source: In this analysis , the submitted predictions on the test data set of the COREF shared task are analyzed according to four types of anaphoric expressions : DNP for definite noun phrases , RELAT for relative pronouns , PRON for other pronouns including personal , possessive , and demonstrative pronouns , and OTHER for catch-all type .
target: In this analysis , the submitted predictions on the test data set of the COREF shared task are analyzed according to four types of anaphoric expressions : DNP for definite noun phrases , RELAT for relative pronouns , PRON for other pronouns including personal , possessive , and demonstrative pronouns , and OTHER for catch-all type .

source: Below are examples of the coreference types .
target: Examples of the coreference types are outlined below :

source: - " . . . ,the phosphorylation status of [ TRAF2 ] had significant effects on the ability of [ the protein ] to bind to CD40 , " ( DNP )
target: - " [ . . . ] the phosphorylation status of [ TRAF2 ] had significant effects on the ability of [ the protein ] to bind to CD40 , " ( DNP )

source: - " Subnuclear fractionation reveals that there are [ two ATF1 isoforms ] [ which ] appear to differ with respect to DNA binding activity , " ( RELAT )
target: - " Subnuclear fractionation reveals that there are [ two ATF1 isoforms , which ] appear to differ with respect to DNA binding activity , " ( RELAT )

source: - " This ability of [ CIITA ] to facilitate promoter occupation is undissociable from [ its ] transactivation potential , " ( PRON )
target: - " This ability of [ CIITA ] to facilitate promoter occupation is undissociable from [ its ] transactivation potential , " ( PRON )

source: The analysis results in also showed that the best resolution results for definite noun phrases ( the DNP type ) , and several pronouns of the PRON type are 27 .5 % F-score and 10 .1 F-score respectively , which are far less than that for relative pronoun ( the RELAT type ) 66 .2 % F-score .
target: An analysis of the results indicated that the best resolution results for definite noun phrases ( the DNP type ) , and several pronouns of the PRON type was 27 .5 % F-score and 10 .1 F-score , respectively ; the scores were much lower than the F-score for relative pronouns ( the RELAT type ) , which yielded a 66 .2 % F-score .

source: Thus , it can be inferred that definite noun phrases and pronouns are more difficult to be resolved than relative pronouns .
target: Thus , it can be inferred that it is more difficult to resolve definite noun phrases and pronouns than relative pronouns .

source: The top four official results of the COREF shared task are shown again in the top four rows of Table 2 .
target: The top four official results of the COREF shared task are presented in the top four rows of Table 2 .

source: In this paper , we compare the contributions of different features in coreference resolution , two simple types of domain-portable information : discourse preference and number-agreement , and domain-specific information which can be considered as more difficult to be transferred across different domains .
target: In this paper , we compare the contributions of different features in coreference resolution ; two simple types of domain-portable information : discourse preference and number-agreement , is compared , as well as domain-specific information , which is considered to be more difficult to be transferred across different domains .

source: We implemented a protein coreference system that makes use of syntactic information from parser output , and protein-indicated information encoded in rule-based semantic classification .
target: We implemented a protein coreference system that makes use of syntactic information from the parser output , and protein-indicated information encoded in rule-based semantic classification .

source: Experimental results showed that domain specific semantic information is important for coreference resolution , and that simple semantic classification using semantic features helped our system to outperform the best reported result in the shared task .
target: Experimental results showed that domain-specific semantic information is important for coreference resolution , and that simple semantic classification using semantic features helped our system to outperform the best-reported system results in the shared task .

source: As we needed to get an insight into the problem , we took a rule-based approach , analyzing the training data of BioNLP-ST 2011 Coref task .
target: In order to acquire insight into the problem , we took a rule-based approach , analyzing the training data of BioNLP-ST 2011 Coref task .

source: The performance of the system evaluated on the official test data set of the COREF task shows a significant improvement over the official winning system of the task .
target: The performance of the system evaluated on the official test dataset of the COREF task shows a significant improvement over the official winning system of the task .

source: This section presents the overview and the performance evaluation of our system .
target: This section presents the overview and the performance evaluation of our system .

source: Figure 2 shows the overall design of the system , which includes five main components : preprocessing , markable detection , anaphor selection , antecedent candidate selection , and antecedent prediction .
target: Figure 2 shows the overall design of the system , which includes five main components : preprocessing , markable detection , anaphor selection , antecedent candidate selection , and antecedent prediction .

source: Processing of each component is briefly described as below .
target: Processing of each component is briefly described below .

source: More details of implementation can be found in the method section .
target: More details of implementation can be found in the method section .

source: Step 0 - Preprocessing : The input text is preprocessed using NLP tools for sentence segmentation , and syntactic parsing .
target: Step 0 - Preprocessing : The input text is preprocessed using NLP tools for sentence segmentation , and syntactic parsing .

source: We used Genia Sentence Splitter and Enju Parser [ 15 ] for the purposes , respectively .
target: We used the Genia Sentence Splitter and Enju Parser [ 15 ] for sentence segmentation and syntactic parsing , respectively .

source: ( Enju parser comes with a default tokenizer and part-of-speech tagger for biological text . ) Row 1 in the example Table 1 shows three sentences outputted from Genia Sentence Splitter , and noun phrases outputted from Enju Parser for the sentence S3 .
target: ( Enju parser comes with a default tokenizer and part-of-speech tagger for biological text . ) Row 1 in the example of Table 1 shows three sentences as the output from the Genia Sentence Splitter , and noun phrases as the output from the Enju Parser for the sentence , S3 .

source: Due to the limit of space , only a part of the phrases are shown in the table .
target: Due to the limited space , only a part of the phrases are shown in the table .

source: The full parse tree of this sentence is separately shown in Figure 3 .
target: The full parse tree for this sentence is separately shown in Figure 3 .

source: Step 1 - Markable detection : collects text chunks that are candidate coreferential expressions , which are also called markables following the jargon of MUC-7 .
target: Step 1 - Markable detection : Text chunks that are candidate coreferential expressions , which are also called markables following the jargon of MUC-7 , are collected .

source: For the set of markables , noun phrases , which do not include subordinate clause , are collected as analyzed by a syntactic parser , Enju in our case .
target: For the set of markables , noun phrases , which do not include a subordinate clause , are collected as they are analyzed by a syntactic parser ( in our case , Enju ) .

source: Pronouns are also collected as markables .
target: Pronouns are also collected as markables .

source: Then , for chunks that share the same head word , which is normally the main noun of a noun phrase , only the longest is taken .
target: Then , for chunks that share the same head word , which is normally the main noun of a noun phrase , only the longest chunk is taken .

source: Since the Enju parser output such head-word information for every noun phrase , we make use of this information for our processing without any modification .
target: Since the Enju parser outputs head-word information for every noun phrase , we make use of this information for our processing , without any modification .

source: The third row of Table 1 shows the result of markable detection for the sample text .
target: The third row of Table 1 shows the result of markable detection for the sample text .

source: In the sentence S3 , three noun phrases recognized by the NX and NP tags of Enju output , role , role for c-Myc in apoptosis , and this role for c-Myc in apoptosis ( Step 0 results ) share the same head word role , thus only the longest one this role for c-Myc in apoptosis is selected .
target: In the sentence S3 , three noun phrases recognized by the NX and NP tags of the Enju output , role , role for c-Myc in apoptosis , and this role for c-Myc in apoptosis ( Step 0 results ) share the same head-word role ; thus , only the longest noun phrase , this role for c-Myc in apoptosis , is selected .

source: However , between studies and studies using . . .
target: However , between studies and studies using . . .

source: apoptosis , the former chunk is selected , since the latter contains a subordinate clause .
target: apoptosis , the former chunk is selected , since the latter contains a subordinate clause .

source: Step 2 - Anaphor selection : determines candidate anaphoric expressions , which are basically pronouns and definite noun phrases ( a minority of anaphors are indefinite noun phrases or entity names , which act as appositions . )
target: Step 2 - Anaphor selection : Candidate anaphoric expressions , which are basically pronouns and definite noun phrases , are determined . A minority of anaphors are indefinite noun phrases or entity names , which act as appositions .

source: The system first considers all pronouns and definite noun phrases in the markable set as anaphors .
target: The system first considers all pronouns and definite noun phrases in the markable set as anaphors .

source: Then , several filters are applied to remove anaphors that are not relevant to the task definition .
target: Then , several filters are applied to remove anaphors that are not relevant to the task definition .

source: We implemented two types of filters : syntactic and semantic filters .
target: We implemented two types of filters : syntactic and semantic .

source: Syntactic filters are used to filter out pleonastic its , or pronouns such as he , she , which are not expected to refer to proteins .
target: Syntactic filters are used to filter out pleonastic its , or pronouns , like : he , she , which are not expected to refer to proteins .

source: Moreover , because the focus of our task is protein references , semantic filters can be used to filter out non-protein anaphors at this stage .
target: Moreover , because our task focuses on protein references , semantic filters can be used to filter out non-protein anaphors at this stage .

source: In practice , for definite noun phrase type of anaphors , this is done using a list of possible head words of protein references , and for pronouns , their context words are used .
target: In practice , for definite noun phrase type of anaphors , this is accomplished , by using a list of possible head-words of protein references ; for pronouns , their context words are used .

source: More details of the methods can be found in the following section .
target: More details of these methods can be found in the following section .

source: Step 3 - Antecedent candidate selection : For each anaphor , this component collects the antecedent candidates from the preceding expressions .
target: Step 3 - Antecedent candidate selection : For each anaphor , this component collects the antecedent candidates from the preceding expressions .

source: One of the candidates will become the response antecedent as a result of the antecedent prediction step .
target: One of the candidates will become the response antecedent , as a result of the antecedent prediction step .

source: In theory , all expressions in the set of markables can become antecedent candidates , however too much candidates makes it difficult to achieve correct antecedent prediction .
target: In theory , all expressions in the set of markables can become antecedent candidates ; however , too many candidates makes it difficult to achieve correct antecedent prediction .

source: Moreover , we also filter out candidates that violate syntactic or semantic constraints raised by the anaphor .
target: Moreover , we also filter out candidates that violate syntactic or semantic constraints raised by the anaphor .

source: In our system , this is done by using a window size in sentences , together with several syntactic filters .
target: In our system , this is done by using a particular window size in sentences , together with several syntactic filters .

source: One of the syntactic filters is based on syntactic relations among phrases outputted from the parser .
target: One of the syntactic filters is based on syntactic relations among phrases outputted from the parser .

source: The idea behind this is that some types of syntactic relations imply the impossibility of coreference relations between its argument noun phrases and the inclusive expressions of these noun phrases .
target: The idea behind this filter is that some types of syntactic relations imply the impossibility of coreference relations between its argument noun phrases and the inclusive expressions of these noun phrases .

source: For example , the two expressions dominant negative form and its in our example in Table 1 , can not be coreferential with each other , since they are connected via the preposition of .
target: For example , the two expressions : dominant negative form and its in our example in Table 1 , cannot be coreferential with each other , since they are connected via the preposition of .

source: Another syntactic filter removes pronouns which are not in the same pronoun family as the anaphor .
target: Another syntactic filter removes pronouns that are not in the same pronoun family as the anaphor .

source: This results in the disappearance of this in candidate antecedents of its .
target: This results in the disappearance of this in candidate antecedents of its .

source: Pronouns in the same family as its are its , it , and itself .
target: Pronouns in the same family as its are its , it , and itself .

source: Step 4 - Antecedent predicion : selects the best candidate in the antecedent candidate set , and forms a response coreference link .
target: Step 4 - Antecedent prediction : The best candidate in the antecedent candidate set is selected , and a response coreference link is formed .

source: Antecedent candidates are compared with one another using a comparison procedure .
target: Antecedent candidates are compared with one another using a comparison procedure .

source: This procedure implements a decision rule list containing four rules , encoding the following selection preference conditions :
target: This procedure implements a decision rule list containing four rules , encoding the following selection preference conditions :

source: -Rule 1 ( Number agreement - NUM-AGREE ) : The candidate which is not number conflict with anaphor is selected .
target: -Rule 1 ( Number agreement - NUM-AGREE ) : The candidate , which does not conflict in number with the anaphor , is selected .

source: -Rule 2 ( Semantic constraint - SEM-CONS ) : If anaphor is a protein reference , then protein candidate is selected .
target: -Rule 2 ( Semantic constraint - SEM-CONS ) : If the anaphor is a protein reference , then a protein candidate is selected .

source: -Rule 3 ( Discourse preference - DISC-PREF ) : According to the anaphor type , the farther candidate is selected .
target: -Rule 3 ( Discourse preference - DISC-PREF ) : According to the anaphor type , the farther candidate is selected .

source: -Default rule ( Default discourse preference - DEFAULT ) : The closer candidate is selected .
target: -Default rule ( Default discourse preference - DEFAULT ) : The closer candidate is selected .

source: The rules are implemented using different features of expressions such as syntactic types of expression , head noun , semantic types , etc . , in a similar way to [ 22 ] .
target: The rules are implemented using different features of expressions , such as syntactic types of expressions , head noun , semantic types , etc . , in a similar way to [ 22 ] .

source: Each rule in the decision list compares two candidates , and returns the preferrable candidate in concern with the anaphor .
target: Each rule in the decision list compares two candidates , and returns the preferable candidate in concern with the anaphor .

source: If equility happens , the next rule in the list is applied .
target: If equility happens , the next rule in the list is applied .

source: The default and also last rule in the decision rule list is special in the sense that depending on the anaphor , it prefers the closer or the farther candidate .
target: The default and also last rule in the decision rule list is special in the sense that depending on the anaphor , it prefers the closer or the farther candidate .

source: Thanks to this rule , the decision list never results in the equility result .
target: Because of this particular rule , the decision list never results in the equility result .

source: By this way , candidates can be sorted , and the best candidate is selected as antecedent .
target: In this way , candidates can be sorted , and the best candidate is selected as the antecedent .
